awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Lighthouse CC:  Professional Development for Community College Computer Science Faculty
awd_abstract_narration:
This project (Lighthouse CC) is focused on providing community college computing faculty with the motivation and knowledge to attract and retain more students, and improve the diversity of computer science majors. It explicitly addresses the large and persistent under-representation of women and minority students majoring in computing.  It is building on a set of earlier projects (Lighthouse, Tapestry) that have been engaged in training educators at the high school level to increase diversity in computing, a discipline skill that is critical for the future US economy. The first stage of the Lighthouse CC project is developing and testing new broadening participation content for community college instructors.  Subsequently, it will build and test a new open online professional development course designed in accordance with John Keller's ARCS Theory of Motivational Design (as explained in "Motivational Design for Learning and Performance: The ARCS model approach," New York: Springer, 2010).  ARCS has four design principles: attention, relevance, confidence, and satisfaction. 

The open online learning environment will provide a platform for educational research into the learning, behavioral, and diversity outcomes of enrolled instructors. This aspect of Lighthouse CC will deepen understanding of the relationship between learner motivation and learning environment. It will provide both research findings and a significant lasting infrastructure in the form of tools, data and content for researchers, practitioners and lifelong learners. The final goal is for this course to become an ongoing professional development course that is both open and online. The intention is make this a go-to professional development course so that the enrollment rises to the level of "massive," thus legitimizing the label MOOC (Massive, Open, Online Course). To maximize impact, Lighthouse CC will widely disseminate and promote adoption of its content by using openly accessible digital resources and an online social network, both of which will be amplified with support from the National Center for Women & IT (NCWIT) and other collaborating groups.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

por.por_cntn:
Lighthouse CC: Professional Development for Community College Computer Science Faculty

Background: The growth in computing occupations is dominating the US workforce while at the same time the discipline fails to attract sufficient and diverse students to meet workforce needs.  Projected computing job openings far outnumber the likely number of graduates with Associate (AS) and Bachelor’s (BS) degrees in computer sciences. In fact, AS computing degrees have decreased over the past ten years, especially for women. These declines are especially significant because they occurred as students, especially women and Hispanic and Black men, increasingly began their college careers in community colleges.

Project Goals: The main purpose of this National Science Foundation-funded multi-year year study was to design, develop, administer, and evaluate an educational theory-based professional development Massive Open Online Course (MOOC) for community college (CC) computing faculty using tested content for recruiting and retaining more and diverse students. The aim of this project was to increase the number of CC computing faculty employing best practice diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) pedagogy and, as a result, increase the number, diversity, and retention of community college computing students.

 

Why focus on Community College? That’s  where the diversity is. Hispanic and Black men, and women of all races, are better represented in CC than in 4-year colleges and universities. CC faculty provide the first introduction for many to computing as a field. However, to be effective in helping broaden participation, community college faculty need high-quality, easy-to-access professional development.

Study Design: The mixed-methods study began with a Needs Assessment (NA) survey administered via SurveyMonkey to a random sample of CC computing faculty (n=50) to identify DEI and other topics of interest for a professional development course. The NA survey was chosen to identify topics of most value quickly and reliably for potential learners. Learning content for five key topics identified from the NA survey was developed using evidence-based research, and then was piloted and validated at two face-to-face workshops. The content validation included pre- (n=30) and post-surveys (n=30) and focus group interviews (n=4) with participants. The learning content and format were then iterated and developed into five core online learning modules on diversity in computing; inclusive pedagogy; stereotype threat; active recruiting; and a case study on strategy implementation. The five-week online course, developed in Open edX, included 5 modules centered around easily digested, short (4-minute average) video-based lectures, post-module quizzes, peer review assignments, a discussion forum, and a final test. An open, online course was chosen to remove barriers to content access by providing a no-cost, easily obtainable course for learners. Peer review assignments and a discussion forum were included to reinforce learning and encourage learners to connect with one another to develop a community of practice that might continue post-course. The course was evaluated using post-completion surveys (n=354), and focus group interviews. Quantitative and qualitative methods were chosen to triangulate findings and to glean insights from participants about their learning. Course data was analyzed to reveal course retention/attrition rates. Focus group interviews and open-ended survey questions were transcribed, and the transcripts were analyzed using ATLAS.ti to perform thematic analyses to uncover key issues and insights. SurveyMonkey was used for questionnaire construction and survey administration. Excel and SPSS were used for analyzing quantitative data.

Project roles: The multidisciplinary project team consisted of a social scientist, an education researcher/instructional designer, two computer science faculty members, a computing engineer, and a research/course assistant. An advisory board consisting of experts in professional development, diversity in computing, CC computing faculty, and CC administrators provided project feedback to the team.

Study Findings and Impact:  The Lighthouse CC course increased learner engagement, reduced course attrition rates, and improved course evaluation ratings. At the CC faculty level - The Lighthouse CC professional development courses and workshops increase the number and the diversity of students that Lighthouse CC research participants attributed to applying strategies they learned from the DEI-focused professional development.


Last Modified: 07/22/2022
Modified by: James P Cohoon
